Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: I was scrubbing the kitchen floor, sweat beading on my forehead, when I heard the front door creak open. My stepbrother, Jamie, darted outside, his shoes barely on. I remembered Mrs. Patel’s strict instructions: every room had to be spotless by noon, and I was already behind. But as I glanced out the window, I saw Jamie heading straight for the busy street, not even glancing up from his phone. My heart pounded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe. But as the housekeeper, I was expected to finish cleaning, no excuses. If I left now, I’d never finish in time, and I’d risk losing my job. If I stayed, Jamie could get hurt. My hands trembled, torn between the mop and the door, between the demands of family and work, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
